messageBody:
What you suggest is a standard pattern in our tests, e.g.:

When both class B and C extend the (abstract) class A, we often have
three test classes: ATest which is abstract itself:

public abstract class ATest extends TestCase {
protected A objectUnderTest;
protected abstract A createObjectUnderTest();
protected setUp() {
A = this.createObjectUnderTest();
}
public void test1() {
objectUnderTest.doSomething();
assert(objectUnderTest.testSomething());
}
public void test2() {
...
}
...
}

BTest and CTest both extend ATest and implement createObjectUnderTest().
Very often there are additional things to be done during setUp, so
setUp() is enhanced in the concrete test clases. Moreover they will
usually add additional tests which make sense only for instance of B or
C. In that case we provide a method which returns objectUnderTest cast
to B - or C respectively.

You can easily extend that concept to a whole hierarchy of classes or
use it to test several interface implementations.

hope that helps,
Johannes

--
Torsten wrote:
>
> Is it possible to reuse JUnit testclasses? All the examples
> in the documentation inherit directly from TestCase and
> all my attempts failed.
> I'd like to build a hierarchy of testclasses that corresponds
> to that of the classes under test...
>
> TIA,
>
> Torsten
